subject: Re: [junit] how to skip a test at runtime

messageBody:
Vietchau,

There are a couple of options. First, you can run individual methods like this:

public static void main(String... args) {
new JUnitCore().run(Request.method(MyClass.class, "selectedMethodName"));
}

or, if you want more fine-grained control, you can use a Filter:

public static void main(String... args) {
new JUnitCore().run(Request.aClass(MyClass.class).filterWith(new MyFilter()));
}

I take from your post that you'll want to process the args passed in
to figure out the methods that should or shouldn't be run. Let me
know if writing your own main application meets your requirements--if
not, there are other options involving custom runners. Thanks,

David Saff

> select which test to run at runtime. I know that there is the @Ignore

> any other option in JUnit to let users specifies at runtime which tests
> to run? I saw the extension package, which have @Prerequisite annotation
> and will let me create a method eg. IsDBAvailable But I tried to have
> parameters to the method, eg. RunThisTest(String testName) and it would
> not allow me to do so. .. I have too many test cases and I don't want to
> have to write a separate function for each of them. Any suggestion on
> how to skip a test at runtime is appreciated.
